  5. Employee earnings

Overview of employee earnings in the UK: 2017

Important measures of employee earnings, using data from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE). Figures are presented mainly for full-time employees, although some detail for part-time workers is also included.

This is the latest release. View previous releases.

Contact:
Email Roger Smith

Release date:
25 October 2018

Next release:
To be announced

Scenario 1 - lead section with chart

3. Analysis of employee earnings

Median full-time weekly earnings increased 3.5% compared with 2017, to £569

Figure 1: Median full-time gross weekly earnings, UK, April 2006 to 2018

2006200720082009201020112012201320142015201620172018
0100200300400500600
£

Source: Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE) - Office for National Statistics

Notes:

  1. Footnotes applicable to all charts in this bulletin can be found in Section 5: Measuring these data.
  2. Notes notes notes
  3. Notes notes notes
Download this chart
Image .csv .xls

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

Scenario 2 - lead subsection with a chart

3. Analysis of employee earnings

Unemployment has gone down

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

Scenario 3 - chart comes after paragraph

3. Analysis of employee earnings

Median full-time weekly earnings increased 3.5% compared with 2017, to £569

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

Scenario 4 - chart under h4

3. Analysis of employee earnings

Weekly earnings have gone up

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.

While the differences seen in these offences estimated by the CSEW are not statistically significant, the pattern appears to be similar to police recorded crime. Both crime types are thought to be generally well-reported by victims and well-recorded by the police and so we believe the recent increases reflect genuine rises.
